TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national of the NORP ethnic origin , born in DATE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
CARDINAL . Proceedings determining the applicant ’s status in GPE

The applicant entered GPE illegally on an unspecified date in DATE . He immediately claimed asylum on the ground that he had allegedly taken part in various hostilities against the NORP military forces and that he feared persecution if returned to GPE . He alleged that he had been previously detained by NORP military officers , that he had been beaten and tortured during that detention , and that he had only been released after his relatives had “ paid a ransom ” .

On DATE the immigration authorities refused asylum and applied to a court for the applicant ’s deportation to GPE . In reaching their conclusion , the immigration authorities referred to the “ danger to national security ” which the applicant represented . No factual elements were specified to support that statement , the immigration authorities having reached the conclusion on the basis of a letter sent to them by ORG . The decision of CARDINAL DATE mentioned that the applicant had the right of appeal to a court within DATE of the notification of the decision , pursuant to LAW .
The decision of CARDINAL DATE was translated into NORP and given to the applicant on DATE , as confirmed by his signature on a copy of the decision submitted to the ORG .
On DATE ORG accepted the immigration authorities’ request to deport the applicant to GPE on the basis of his presenting a danger to national security .
On DATE the applicant was accommodated at ORG ( ARC ) pending the final determination of his legal status in GPE .
On DATE the applicant applied to a court , claiming asylum and alleging persecution in GPE .

On DATE ORG dismissed the application on the ground that the applicant had missed DATE time - limit for the submission of an appeal , laid down in LAW . In this regard it was noted that the applicant had sent his application by post only on DATE . The court also noted that the applicant had not specified whether his application was an appeal against the immigration authorities’ decision of CARDINAL DATE , or against the court decision of DATE . In either event , the applicant had submitted his appeal out of time . It was further noted that he had not requested an extension of the time - limit for appeal .

On DATE the applicant received the court decision of CARDINAL DATE . On DATE he consulted a lawyer , who helped him to draft a further appeal against the immigration authorities’ decision of CARDINAL DATE . In that appeal , dated DATE , the applicant stated that he had only taken cognisance of the impugned decision on DATE , and that he had appealed against it on DATE . Since he did not have a lawyer until DATE , the applicant requested the reinstatement of the time - limit for appealing against the decision of CARDINAL DATE . In his appeal , the applicant argued that the authorities’ conclusions on his alleged “ danger to national security ” were not supported by any evidence . He claimed that he would be subjected to persecution if returned to GPE .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s request to reinstate the time - limit . The court held that the time - limit mentioned in LAW could only be reinstated in cases where it had been missed as a result of circumstances independent of the applicant ’s will . However , the court observed that the applicant had not invoked any circumstances which could show that he was not in a position to submit his appeal before DATE .

On DATE the applicant filed an appeal against the decision of DATE . The applicant stated that from DATE , after having taken cognisance of the decision of CARDINAL DATE , he had been unable to submit his appeal within the DATE period since he did not know the NORP language or legislation and , moreover , had no postage stamps or envelopes to send an appeal . According to the applicant , on DATE he had given his appeal , which had been written in LANGUAGE , to a representative of the ORG High Commissioner for Refugees ( ORG ) , who in turn sent the appeal to the court . The applicant also stated that the ORG representative had promised the applicant that he would inform certain immigration lawyers about his situation . As a result , the applicant had been able to meet a lawyer for the first time on DATE , and to draft a properly motivated appeal on DATE .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal against the decision of DATE . The court reiterated that the applicant ’s first appeal against the decision of DATE had only been sent on DATE , i.e. DATE after the applicant had familiarised himself with the decision ( of DATE ) . The court observed that the fact that the applicant had access to a lawyer for the first time only on DATE did not constitute a circumstance absolving him from the obligation to comply with the time - limit . The court also stated that the other allegations relied on by the applicant ( i.e. ignorance of language and laws , and no stationery ) could not be reviewed on appeal as these facts had not been alleged before the first - instance court on DATE . That decision was final .
On DATE ORG communicated the applicant ’s complaints about his imminent expulsion from GPE to GPE under LAW .
On DATE ORG suspended the execution of the expulsion order of DATE .
On DATE the immigration authorities authorised the applicant ’s stay in GPE on humanitarian grounds .

On DATE the President of ORG petitioned ORG to resume the proceedings concerning the applicant ’s expulsion . On DATE ORG accepted the President ’s petition . The case was transmitted for a fresh examination by ORG .
On DATE ORG quashed the expulsion order of DATE inter alia because of a risk of the applicant ’s possible persecution if deported to GPE .
On DATE the immigration authorities issued the applicant with a temporary residence permit on humanitarian grounds .
In his letter of DATE , the applicant stated that , in view of the regularisation of his stay in GPE , he no longer wished to pursue his complaints under LAW .
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s detention
The applicant had not been arrested or detained upon his entry into GPE in DATE or immediately thereafter . In DATE he lived at an address in GPE .

On DATE the immigration authorities informed ORG that the applicant had not been found at his permanent place of residence , and that as a result he not been acquainted with the decision of CARDINAL DATE refusing asylum .
On DATE the applicant was arrested by the NORP police in view of the expulsion order of DATE .

On DATE the applicant ’s detention ( sulaikymas ) and placement ( apgyvendinimas ) at the ARC were authorised by GPE to ensure the applicant ’s eventual expulsion from GPE on the basis of LAW ( see the “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” part below ) . Detention was authorised until DATE .
On the same date the applicant escaped from the police . A search for him was launched . On DATE he was again arrested , brought to and accommodated at the ARC .
On DATE , DATE and DATE , ORG extended the term of the applicant ’s detention , by the latter decision until DATE .
On DATE ORG refused to order the applicant ’s release .

On DATE ORG dismissed his appeal against the decision of DATE . In this connection the appeal court noted that the decision on the applicant ’s expulsion had not been quashed , although its execution had been suspended by ORG on DATE . It held that the applicant ’s continuing detention was compatible with LAW and CARDINAL of LAW ( see the “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” part below ) .

On DATE ORG refused to order the applicant ’s release . On DATE the ORG further authorised the applicant ’s detention at the ARC until DATE . The court noted that on DATE the immigration authorities had decided to authorise the applicant ’s stay in the country on humanitarian grounds , and that , as a result , the ground specified in LAW , namely the unlawfulness of his stay in the country , could no longer justify his detention . However , the court observed that the continuing validity of the expulsion order of DATE warranted his detention in accordance with LAW and CARDINAL of LAW .
On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal against the decision of DATE .
On DATE ORG quashed the expulsion order of DATE inter alia because of a risk of the applicant ’s possible persecution if deported to GPE .
In view of this decision , on DATE ORG decided that there were no longer any grounds for the applicant ’s detention under LAW . The decision of DATE was accordingly quashed .

On DATE , upon the applicant ’s request , his further stay at the ARC was authorised by the immigration authorities under a different regime , namely without any restrictions on his liberty of movement .

Following the decision of DATE to issue the applicant with a temporary residence permit , he left his accommodation at the ARC on an unspecified date in DATE . It appears that he now lives in a place of his own choice in GPE .

According to LAW of DATE , an alien can be arrested ( sulaikytas ) by the police and held for TIME , in order to determine the legality of his stay in the country . The alien can thereafter be deprived of his liberty only on the basis of a court order .

Pursuant to LAW , an alien may be detained ( sulaikytas ) if his stay in the country is illegal ( LAW ) , where a decision has been taken to expel him ( LAW ) , or when he presents a danger to public safety and national security ( LAW ) .
According to LAW , the immigration authorities shall apply to a court for a detention order if one of the grounds specified in LAW exists .
